status_notes: Case Noted. Thank you for sharing your concern. The City of Boston opted in to adopt a lower default speed limit of 25 mph unless otherwise posted. Default speed limits are citywide, and are not posted on each block. We are limited to posting regulatory speed limit signs to locations with a speed zone regulation approved by MassDOT. However, we have installed several 25 mph signs at entry points to the city. If there is a more specific concern, we may be able to evaluate the issue. We invite you to document safety concerns on the Vision Zero Safety Concerns map: http://app01.cityofboston.gov/VZSafety/. The City uses this data to prioritize countermeasures and upcoming safety projects. To get updates in your inbox, please join the mailing list at visionzeroboston.org/contact.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. . The Boston Public Works Department Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) has identified the sidewalk left in asphalt as belonging to Eversource. All permittees are required to restore the sidewalk to its original condition within 60 days of the completion of the work. This particular location is under 60 days old. Since we have a moratorium on concrete work after November 15th unless the weather are conducive for concrete pouring after November 15th, the restoration work may have to wait until next Spring. The location has been entered into the CIU data base that tracks sidewalk cuts left in HMA needing to be restored within 60 days. The CIU Inspector will periodically check the condition of the asphalt patch. If the asphalt patch does not meet our standards they will need to repair the asphalt ASAP until the permanent restoration is scheduled. The CIU will monitor the progress of the repair. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

However, we have installed several 25 mph signs at entry points to the city. If there is a more specific concern, we may be able to evaluate the issue. status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) know one of its most important responsibilities is to make sure utilities and private contractors are following our no parking procedures. For example:Some jobs will require installing a new main usually for hundreds of feet and in some cases the entire street, we have told the utility companies and private contractors to only post where they will be for the next week or so. This will allow more parking on the street. The City's goal is to provide as much marking as possible during construction. We have provided them labels to change the dates as they move down the street. In this particular case we will talk to Verizon and make sure that the signs that were previously posted had the dates changed to reflect the new work dates. If this wasn't the case, we will have them take the signs down and repost. We did tell utility companies and contractors that there was no work from the 23rd-26th to allow residents to enjoy the long Thanksgiving weekend without construction. This may have contributed to the confusion. We apologize for the inconvenience you incurred. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.
